description: From Middle English dryvyng, drivende, from Old English drīfende, from Proto-Germanic *drībandz, present participle of Proto-Germanic *drībaną (“to drive”), equivalent to drive +‎ -ing. Cognate with Saterland Frisian drieuwend, West Frisian driuwend, Dutch drijvend, German Low German drievend, German treibend, Swedish drivande.

adjectives.description: driving (comparative more driving, superlative most driving)

entries.meaning: (of wind, rain, etc): That drives forcefully; strong; forceful; violent

description: From Middle English driving, drivinge, equivalent to drive +‎ -ing. Compare Dutch drijving, German Treibung.

entries.meaning: The action of the verb to drive in any sense.
examples: […]  with all its drivings of cattle and all its tithe battles, and all the killings and maimings consequent upon those battles,  […]

entries.meaning: In particular, the action of operating a motor vehicle.
(golf) The act of driving the ball; hitting the ball a long distance, especially from the tee to the putting green.
